text.p: These are the leading stories in the Kenyan press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Ministers Musalia Mudavadi and William ole Ntimama are among government officials named in parliament as beneficiaries of land controversially hived off from Nairobi's City Park.
- The National Electoral Commission validates the use of the old and new generation identity cards for voter registration which begins on Monday.
- Foreign Affairs Minister Kalonzo Musyoka denies he is being sidelined and that was excluded from peace talks between Sudan and Uganda hosted by Kenya last week.
- Opposition party FORD-Asili is headed for another show-down following an announcement by Secretary-General Martin Shikuku that it will hold grassroot elections.
- The Central Bank of Kenya sends out an alert over what it says are businessman who defrauded financial institutions and major companies over two billion shillings ($37.04 million)
- Armed cattle rustlers kill eleven people in Marakwet District, Rift Valley.
- Two people are set ablaze and killed by members of the public after snatching a necklace from a woman in Mombasa.
- President Daniel arap Moi tells Kenyans to evaluate the honesty, competence and ideals of leaders they intend to elect.
- Seventeen leaders from the ruling party defend Nyanza Provincial Commissioner Joseph Kaguthi, saying he is being dragged into a blackmail scheme aimed at weakening the party.

- Kerio East member of parliament Frederick Cheserek makes history as the first parliamentarian from the ruling party to challenge President Moi's leadership for not providing adequate security for his constituents from cattle rustlers. ($1=54 Kenya Shillings)
